question: Who was living with his parents?
answer1: Wassamo

question: Where did Wassamo and his parents live?
answer1: far out in the north-east

question: What did Wassamo and the cousin use to shelter them through the night?
answer1: the bark of the birch

question: How did Wassamo and his cousin feel when they drew up the nets?
answer1: rejoiced

question: What did the cousin do while Wassamo cooked?
answer1: laid at his ease upon the other side of the fire

question: Why did the cousin fall away?
answer1: ran his length

question: What did Wassamo do after he lifted the kettle from the fire?
answer1: spoke to his cousin

question: Why did Wassamo take the wooden ladle and skim the kettle?
answer1: fish were very plump and fat

question: Who were the two persons Wassamo saw at no great distance?
answer1: two beautiful young females

question: What happened to Wassamo after he approached the women?
answer1: suddenly fell to the earth

question: What made the cousin wake up?
answer1: a gentle sound of music and soft voices accompanying Wassamo and the women's vanishing

question: What did the cousin believe Wassamo was doing when he could not find him?
answer1: gone out again to visit the nets

question: How did the cousin feel when he could not find Wassamo?
answer1: greatly troubled
answer2: sorrow

question: Why did the cousin not believe that Wassamo was playing a trick on him?
answer1: It was full time that the trick should be at an end, and Wassamo returned not.

question: What did the village say when the saw the cousin approaching at such speed and alone?
answer1: "Some accident has happened."

question: What happened to the cousin's other hopes after he found himself alone by the hunting-fire?
answer1: They all died away in the morning light.

question: Where did many of the men visit?
answer1: the fish-fire

question: What did the men do when they couldn't find Wassamo?
answer1: returned to the village

question: Why did some of the men think that it was impossible for the cousin to kill Wassamo?
answer1: Wassamo and the cousin were like brothers.
answer2: There were no marks of blood.
answer3: No hasty steps were there to show that any conflict or struggle had occurred.

question: Who looked to see Wassamo more?
answer1: the parents

question: Why did Netawis say he was not afraid to die?
answer1: He was innocent of the great wrong they laid to his charge.

question: Where did Netawis wander?
answer1: along the shore of the lake

question: What made Netawis stop himself from taking his own life?
answer1: The village would say that he was guilty if he took his own life.

question: What happened to Wassamo after he fell senseless before the two young women in the wood?
answer1: He lost all knowledge of himself until he wakened in a distant scene.

question: Who spoke to Wassamo first?
answer1: the Old Spirit-man
answer2: the guardian Spirit of the Sand Mountains

question: What did the Old Spirit-man wish?
answer1: get one of Wassamo's race to marry among his people

question: What will the Old Spirit-man do if Wassamo makes up his mind to remain?
answer1: give Wassamo one of his daughters--the one who smiled on Wassamo first

question: Who was the Old Spirit's bitter enemy?
answer1: that Spirit who rules all islands lying in the lakes

question: What did the Old Spirit-man do as the guardian Spirit of the Sand Mountains?
answer1: pile sand up, and blow them about, and do whatever he will with them

question: What did the Old Spirit want from Wassamo?
answer1: tobacco

question: How did the gifts come to the Old Spirit?
answer1: by putting his hand out of the side of the lodge

question: What did the Sand-Spirits do after he heard a loud rattling of thunder?
answer1: vanished out of sight

question: Why was the cupboard never empty?
answer1: In there were all of the offerings handed in while they were asleep.

question: What happened after the season of the Sand-Spirits' vanishing?
answer1: They laid themselves down to the long slumber.

question: What did the Old Spirit do before he yielded?
answer1: had his last sport with the sand-hills, and he so tossed and vexed the poor hills, and scattered them to and fro, and whirled them up in the air, and far over the land

question: How did Wassamo amuse himself?
answer1: looked into the cupboard
answer2: found a fresh supply of game and every other dainty which his heart desired
answer3: listened to the voices of the travelers who passed by the window at the side of the lodge

question: Why was Wassamo rewarded by the Old Spirit?
answer1: Wassamo had been very patient with the Old Spirit's long absence.

question: Why did the Old Spirit say to not be surprised whenever the wife disappeared at the sound of thunder?
answer1: The old Island Spirit has a brother down in that part of the country.

question: What would the wife do while Wassamo slept?
answer1: be at work

question: Who did Wassamo see as he turned the first point of land by the lake?
answer1: Netawis

question: How did the village feel when they saw Wassamo?
answer1: joyful

question: What did the Indian people find themselves astonished by when they saw Wassamo's wife?
answer1: her beauty, at the whiteness of her skin, and that she was able to talk with them in their own language

question: What did the wife tell her husband before lying down?
answer1: "No one but yourself must pass on this side of the lodge."

question: What did Wassamo reply he would do with the people's requests?
answer1: mention each of their requests to his father-in-law

question: How did the village ensure that there would be no mistake as to their wants?
answer1: Each one who had given tobacco had painted and marked in distinct characters the totem or family emblem of his family and tribe.

question: How did the old Sand-Spirit feel when he saw Wassamo and his wife?
answer1: delighted

question: What did the Old Spirit reply regarding the requests of the Indian people?
answer1: He would attend to all, but he must first invite his friends to smoke with him.

question: Which manito wished to marry the Old Spirit's daughter?
answer1: Island Spirit

question: What will happen if Wassamo does not sit close by his wife?
answer1: He will be lost.

question: What did Wassamo hear?
answer1: a great rumbling and roaring, as of waters tumbling over rocks

question: Why did the wicked Island Spirit look grim enough at Wassamo's wife?
answer1: She had rejected him.

question: What did Wassamo request?
answer1: no sand-squalls among his father's people for three months to come

question: How was the tobacco divided?
answer1: in equal shares among the company

question: Why was Wassamo's wife tarried at home?
answer1: to look after a son

question: What did Wassamo's name change to?
answer1: Feather of Flames, Wassamo of the Fire-Plume

question: What happened after Wassamo delivered all of his messages and passed a happy time?
answer1: Wassamo said, "I must now bid you all farewell forever."

question: What was the special favor Wassamo could now grant?
answer1: Wassamo allowed his parents and friends to accompany him to the sand-banks.

question: What made Wassamo believe that he and his cousin were fortunate?
answer1: The weather was clear.
answer2: There were little black spots on the water towards their nets.
answer3: Everything was calm.

question: Why was Wassamo trying to wake his cousin up so frantically?
answer1: His cousin did not wake up.
answer2: Wassamo was afraid of the women.
answer3: The cousin made no reply.

question: How will Wassamo feel when he sees the women?
answer1: amazed
answer2: surprised
answer3: scared

question: What made the cousin believe Wassamo would appear?
answer1: The fire flickered and made light and shadow.
answer2: Some of the fish were in the bowl.
answer3: He did not think Wassamo would leave him alone.

question: Why was the cousin worried about Wassamo's disappearance?
answer1: He cared for Wassamo.
answer2: Wassamo's parents would have thought that he had slain Wassamo.
answer3: He did not want to be punished by Wassamo's parents.

question: Why did the village have a struggle of pity?
answer1: They did not believe Netawis killed Wassamo.
answer2: They thought Netawis and Wassamo were as close as brothers.
answer3: Netawis was innocent.

question: How will Wassamo's parents feel towards Netawis?
answer1: vengeful
answer2: hatred
answer3: angry

question: Why did Wassamo drop his head and make no answer?
answer1: He did not agree to the Old Spirit-man's wish.
answer2: He did not want to stay under the earth.
answer3: He wanted to return to his kindred.

question: How will the Old Spirit's daughter feel about marrying Wassamo?
answer1: happy
answer2: pleased
answer3: excited

question: Why did the Old Spirit highly value tobacco?
answer1: It was a rare plant.
answer2: He loved tobacco.
answer3: Tobacco did not grow in this dry place.

question: Why would the Sand-Spirits lie down and not rise until spring?
answer1: It was winter.
answer2: They were hibernating.
answer3: It was too cold.

question: What will the Island Spirit do to Wassamo if he catches him?
answer1: do mischief
answer2: hurt Wassamo

question: What will happen now that the village knows Wassamo is alive?
answer1: The village will not kill Netawis.
answer2: The village will embrace Wassano.
answer3: The village will ask Wassano what happened.

question: Why did the cousin run off with breathless dispatch to the village?
answer1: He wanted to show the village Wassano was alive.
answer2: He did not want to be sentenced to death.
answer3: He wanted to prove he did not kill Wassano.

question: Why did the Old Spirit want Wassamo to leave his wife at a short distance from the lodge?
answer1: He wanted Wassamo to be accepted first.
answer2: He wanted to protect his daughter.
answer3: He wanted his daughter to be accepted by Wassamo's home-village.

question: Why was there a great abundance of tobacco sent to the Old Spirit?
answer1: The Old Spirit told Wassamo to bring him tobacco.
answer2: The village heard the Old Spirit was a magician and guardian of great power.
answer3: The village wanted to send gifts to Wassamo's father-in-law.

question: Why did the cousin keep close by Wassamo?
answer1: He did not want to lose Wassamo again.
answer2: He wanted to know what country Wassamo came from.
answer3: He did not want his life to be threatened.

question: What made the sugar-harvest greater than had been ever known in all that region?
answer1: Wassamo's wife help
answer2: Wassamo's wife's magical father

question: How will the village feel towards Wassamo's wife habit of disappearing at every thunder-storm?
answer1: confused
answer2: unsure
answer3: curious

question: Why did Netawis want to attend Wassamo and his wife at a distance?
answer1: He wanted to know how Wassamo disappeared.
answer2: He wanted to see the magic power.

question: What made the village not doubt the cousin's word in anything?
answer1: The cousin told the truth in the past.
answer2: The cousin was wrongly accused in the past.
answer3: The cousin and Wassamo were as close as brothers.

question: Why did the Old Spirit give a caution to Wassamo?
answer1: He cared for Wassamo.
answer2: He loved his son-in-law.
answer3: He did not want Wassamo to be lost.

question: Why did the Old Spirit's brothers accept Wassamo?
answer1: Wassamo brought tobacco.
answer2: The Old Spirit liked Wassamo.
answer3: Wassamo was the Old Spirit's son-in-law.

question: How will the Old Spirit's brothers feel about the tobacco?
answer1: pleased
answer2: happy
answer3: eager

question: What will the Spirits do after bearing off their tobacco-sacks?
answer1: They will fulfill the people's requests.
answer2: They will depart on their own business.

question: Why did Wassamo's parents and friends raised their voices in loud lamentation?
answer1: Wassamo would no longer visit them.
answer2: They would miss Wassamo.

question: Why is Wassamo not allowed to visit his parents and friends again after another holiday?
answer1: Wassamo was a spirit.
answer2: Wassamo was a member of the great family of Spirits.
answer3: Wassamo was no longer a mortal.
